netgest.bo.xwc.components.classic
Class MessageBox

java.lang.Object
  javax.faces.component.UIComponent
      javax.faces.component.UIComponentBase
          netgest.bo.xwc.framework.components.XUIComponentBase
              netgest.bo.xwc.framework.components.XUIOutput
                  netgest.bo.xwc.framework.components.XUIInput
                      netgest.bo.xwc.components.classic.MessageBox
All Implemented Interfaces:
javax.faces.component.EditableValueHolder, javax.faces.component.StateHolder, javax.faces.component.ValueHolder, netgest.bo.xwc.framework.XUIEditableValueHolder
public class MessageBox
extends netgest.bo.xwc.framework.components.XUIInput

Component to generate different styles of message boxes.

Example of usages

Declaration in a viewer using predefined buttons

                <xvw:messageBox 
                        id='myMessageBox' 
                        messageBoxType='WARNING'
                        buttons='YESNO'
                        actions='["#{viewBean.myYesBeanMethod}","#{viewBean.myNoBeanMethod}"]'
                        title='Message Box Title' 
                        message='My Message Box text' 
        />

Declaration in a viewer using custom buttons

                
         <xvw:messageBox 
                        id='myMessageBoxId' 
                        messageBoxType='WARNING'
                        title='Message Box Title' 
                        defaultConfirmButton='btn1'
                        defaultCancelButton='btn3'
                        message='My Message Box text' 
        >
                <xvw:menu text='Button 1' id='btn1' serverAction='#{viewBean.btn1Action}' />
                <xvw:menu text='Button 2' id='btn2' serverAction='#{viewBean.btn2Action}' />
                <xvw:menu text='Button 3' id='btn3' serverAction='#{viewBean.btn3Action}' />
        </xvw:messageBox>

Showing the Dialog Box in a bean method

                import netgest.bo.xwc.xeo.beans.Dialogs;
                ...
                ...
                public void someMehtod() {
                        Dialogs.showDialog( getViewRoot(), "formId:myMessageBoxId" );   
                }

buttons

private netgest.bo.xwc.framework.XUIBaseProperty<java.lang.String> buttons
The set of buttons to display in the MessageBox, must be one from MessageBox.MessageBoxButtons

actions

private netgest.bo.xwc.framework.XUIBaseProperty<java.lang.String> actions
The set of actions binded to the buttons. If the component has two buttons, it must provide two actions (meaning, the number of actions must match the number of components) To fill this property a JSON Array must be specified, featuring the same number of positions as the number of buttons for the components Eg. If the button used is OKCANCEL a two position array should be provided, the first position with the action for the OK button and the other with the action for the "CANCEL" button, as seen bellow actions="['#{viewBean.myOkAction}','#{viewBean.myCancelAction}']"

messageBoxType

private netgest.bo.xwc.framework.XUIBaseProperty<MessageBox.MessageBoxType> messageBoxType
The icon to be shown in the MessageBox, the types of icon are declared in the MessageBox.MessageBoxType enumeration

defaultConfirmButton

private netgest.bo.xwc.framework.XUIBaseProperty<java.lang.String> defaultConfirmButton
The identifier of the button that'll be invoked when the user presses the ENTER key

defaultCancelButton

private netgest.bo.xwc.framework.XUIBaseProperty<java.lang.String> defaultCancelButton
The identifier of the button that'll be invoked when the user presses the ESC key

setMessageBoxType

public void setMessageBoxType(java.lang.String type)
Sets the message box icon based on the next values. The acceptable values are: ERROR - For error Message Box boxes INFO - For info Message Box boxes QUESTION - For question Message Box boxes WARNING - For warning Message Box boxes

Parameters:
type - the new message box type

getMessageBoxType

public MessageBox.MessageBoxType getMessageBoxType()
Gets the message box icon type.

Returns:
the message box type

setButtons

public void setButtons(java.lang.String btns)
Sets the predefined buttons. The acceptable values are: YES - Add a Yes button to the Message Box OK - Add a OK button in the Message Box YESNO - Add a YES and a NO buttons to the Message Box YESNOCANCEL - Add a Yes, No and Cancel buttons to the Message Box OKCANCEL - Add a OK and Cancel buttons to the Message Box

Parameters:
btns - the new buttons

setButtons

public void setButtons(MessageBox.MessageBoxButtons buttons)
Sets the buttons.

Parameters:
buttons - the new buttons

getButtons

public MessageBox.MessageBoxButtons getButtons()
Gets the buttons.

Returns:
the buttons

setActions

public void setActions(java.lang.String actions)

Sets the actions.

String in the notation JavaScript Array with Method expression's for the pre-configured buttons.
The sequence of the expressions must be the same as the name of predefined buttons.

For example:
In a MessageBox with the buttons OKCANCEL, the string must be like this.
 ['#{viewBean.myOkAction}','#{viewBean.myCancelAction}']

Parameters:
actions - the new actions

getActions

public java.lang.String getActions()
Gets the actions.

Returns:
the actions

Sets the default cancel button. This accept's the id of the child component that should executed when the user closes the dialog or when the presses the Escape Key

Parameters:
expressionText - the new default cancel button
